Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Flash> I need help to figure out what I need to do. I have my seed and my Private_keys for my Hush but I never converted it over to HUSH3 and I am using an agama wallet from like Mar 2018. What are my first steps to even know if my balance is still mine?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Berg> If you have already used Agama in the last 2 months with that seed than its "ok" to use it again to move the funds. If you have not used it for more than 4 months then you can leave them just on the seed. We recommend moving all funds (all coins) out. Use this link to see all your assetchain balance https://dexstats.info/assetviewer.php

How to Generate new address quickly?
Use Verus version of Agama which is not affected -  https://veruscoin.io/wallet.html
1. Start VRSC Lite mode
2. create new seed which will generate new address which is compatible with KMD and all assetchain.  Keed the seed safely backedup (make a note of that address)

Alternative method to generate new address
- Use native mode (best to use CLI) - Safest - Use bootstrap from here if you like https://dexstats.info/bootstrap.php
- Use coinbin (may not be most secure as it's web) - https://deckersu.github.io/coinbin/#newAddress

How to send funds to the new address?
Send all KMD and assetchains funds to that address, even if Verus wallet doesn't support that coin at the moment. As long as you have the seed safe, you can access your funds later.
0. If you have Agama 0.3.5 or 0.3.6b, use that to send funds out or
1. Quickest - Agama webwallet ONLY to send funds out immediately https://www.atomicexplorer.com/wallet/#/
2. You can also use this guide to send all KMD and assetchains to new address. You don't need to use 2 computers. Just use one offline computer https://support.komodoplatform.com/en/support/solutions/articles/29000026631-sign-transactions-offline-and-broadcast-online-using-agama

Where to send funds?
- Another address created by Verus Agama or native mode
- Ledger wallet
- CEX (they are not affected but if you want to)

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> see pinned posts, too

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I don't lightly recommend web wallets, but the web wallet is considered safer than Agama currently, by a long shot

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Flash look at our pinned posts, download the newest Verus agama, and send all funds to that new address from Verus agama (there are also 2 other agama versions that would work, but Verus agama seems to be the most used)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> your seed phrase from regular Agama will work in Verus Agama, but the whole point is to send all funds out of that address

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Flash> Most used means better chance at support😀

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so make a new wallet + seed phrase, write down the address, then log out, use your OLD seed phrase, and then send a transaction with ALL FUNDS to your new address. There is a little "all" button you can click to make it easy

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Flash> Do I need to save the .dat file from old agama wallet?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and make sure to backup your new seed phrase on paper

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Flash never delete a wallet.dat, just in case. Back them up, maybe give them more useful names, like old_agama_wallet.dat

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> also put your address(es) in here: https://dexstats.info/assetviewer.php

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Verify that you have swept all funds from all chains

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Flash> Always have backups. Just need to find the .dat file

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> good luck, sorry for the pain. Hackers gonna hack, I guess. We are learning a lot from this experience

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> this will make GUI wallets in our ecosystem more secure, this incident. Many things will change because of this

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Various other cryptocoins have contacted me, concerned for their own wallets. And they very much have reason to be concerned

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> everyone DO NOT USE `https://www.atomicexplorer.com/wallet/`, it's been compromised. All your funds will be drained upon logging in 😿 . The Hush web wallet is not affected by this

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Hammerstein> @dukeleto  Unsafe to use and/or leave funds in?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Hammerstein I don't trust Agama source code much anymore, regardless of which project has it. Currently Verus Agama is considered safe, but that could change. Full node wallets are safest, and those that don't use nodeJS are much safer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Flash> @dukeleto is superman on this save your Hush front. So glad to see the engagement and concern

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Just trying to do my best to help people protect their funds

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's pretty much my job, I think

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> The Hush web wallet works differently than the KMD web wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> probably a good time for a story around the fire

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> KMD web wallet talks to electrum backend servers, but HUSH web wallet talks to our insight explorer API

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they are actually very very different codebases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> So that, at least, makes me sleep better

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the HUSH web wallet does use Javascript tho, it's not immune to this kind of hack

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it changes very very rarely, is one thing it's got going for it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Hackers go for codebases that constantly change, because that is where you are most likely to get your malware code added

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Flash> The Agama wallet recommendation on https://myhush.org/#agama-section is a no go then right?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> They show up as a helpful github contributor, with a new package that solves some bug. Or they actually solve a bug and use their own malware to "solve" it. Once a few projects use this malware, the attacker begins to plan the attack. The attack is time sensitive, because it gives up the game and the attacker will probably have to get their code into a new project all over again. Attackers try very hard and use a lot of energy to not get caught, because getting caught is their biggest source of work. It makes them find a whole new project to inject their malware

Author: Gateway#3763
